content.description:
Start standing at the base of the faint corner/dihedral feature with the left hand on a sloper/sidepull and the right hand on a high crimp. Follow the shallow dihdedral on slopers, crimps and edges until rock leftward to gain the lip and an easy top out. 

  A good problem with fun movement and perfect rock.
content.protection: A couple of pads are ideal.
content.location: From the parking, head past 'Half Baked...' and down a short hill. This problem is located on the west face of the large boulder in front of you.

content.description:
Sit start just left of the arete, to the right of Dead Center, on obvious opposing sidepulls.  A shouldery move off a bad crimp and possibly a worse intermediate gets you to better holds for a brief respite.  From there a techie sequence on crimps up the face takes you up and left to the initial lip.  Two more moves that can feel a bit desperate when you're tired gains an easy top out. 

  Great movement on perfect crimps. 

  Beware loose rock on the highest left crimp on the route.  Most of it has broken off but be warned.
content.protection: Couple pads and a spotter would be nice.  Couldn't ask for a better landing though
content.location: Climbs the face next to the arete to the right of Dead Center

content.description:
Start sitting with hands matched on the lowest incut crimp rail. Bump the left hand to one of two crimp gastons and then make a powerful pull to another small crimp rail that is a long ways away. Perhaps use a small knobby pinch to get there. If you make it that far, mostly good holds await. Follow these to an easy, but somewhat dirty top out just right of the tree. 

  Sharp, powerful, crimpy- in no particular order. 

  With some traffic, the top out will clean up nicely.
content.location: From the parking head past 'Half Baked...' and down a short hill to a large boulder. This problem can be found on the east face, just right of a large hemlock tree.

climbs.name: Half Baked Over a Puddle of Mud

content.description: A rising arete traverse similar to Arrow in the Trailside area, just a tad higher and longer.  Sit start at the base (when the lagoon is dry) and follow the nicely sculpted arete up and left.
content.location: This arete is on the first set of boulders sitting next to the road.  Hard to miss.

content.description:
Stand start the arete with left hand on a good pinch on the arete and right hand low on a crimp, pick some feet and climb the arete making use of the crimps on the face with your right hand. 

  Pretty good climb, with a bit more traffic the crime should be a bit less sharp.
content.protection: Pad and not falling into the tree
content.location: On the smaller boulder that is right on the waters edge. This climbs the closet arete to the water.

content.description:
Start sitting with both hands on a crimpy flake. Pull up to another good crimp (crux) and continue up the face on edges and rails to a slopey, but relatively straight forward top out. 

  An excellent and aesthetic problem on great rock.
content.location: This is located on the same boulder as 'Trending South' and 'Pace Is The Trick'. It can be found on the south face.

content.description: This line starts with a left hand pinch and right hand gaston and utilizes a high left start foot.  Shoot up and left (crux) to either a sloper or the shallow crescent shaped dish.  Look for the distinct horn out right and your halfway there.  Finish up with more positive holds and toss in in a sloping top-out for good measure.
content.location: Around the corner, walk right of Dead Center.

content.description:
So you're on the slabs, the dome, the lower cliff, or the trailside boulders and you look across the marsh to see a giant boulder hidden in the trees.  Maybe at some point you go look, but most people don't.  What you miss out on is a secluded little area with a bunch of easy to moderate highballs and a few quality shorter problems that in the end would add up to a good day out bouldering. 

  The granite here is the same as Round Pond and the climbs are shaded for most of the day.  There are crimps, cracks, jugs, slopers and even a pocket or two.  The majority of the landings are flat, with one exception - there is a rock sitting beneath a difficult highball.  People have been climbing here for years and you know you're interested, so go take a look.
